text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

While the big money-spinner for Australian universities is still charging overseas students to come to an Australian campus, most of Australia's 37 universities have now established some form of overseas presence to deliver Australian-credentialled course and several universities, including RMIT, Monash, Sydney and NSW are establishing their own branch campuses in Asia. Page 1.

The Federal Government has come under further criticism over its sale of telecommunications giant Telstra. The Opposition and Liberal backbenchers claim full privatisation of the company is on the drawing board, but as amendments to the Telstra bill were eing thrashed out in the Senate yesterday, Prime Minister John Howard assured critics the Government would continue to encourage competition in the telecommunications market. Page 2.

The House of Representatives looks set to pass a vote to override the Northern Territory's euthanasia legislation in what appears to be a decisive majority. Father of the House and former National Party Leader Ian Sinclair called for an amendment to the bll, seeking to put it aside as it was 'discriminatory' against the people of the territories, but the amendment failed 45-82. The Andrews euthanasia bill will go to a Senate inquiry before a Senate vote next year. Page 4.

The Federal Government is yet to make a final decision on the way it will deliver the A$4.5 billion worth of Labor tax cuts which were due this year. The Government has indicated it would like to alter the delivery but has yet to reveal how. The cuts werepart of the One Nation tax amendments in 1992. Page 5.
THE AUSTRALIAN

In what will be the one of the biggest managerial shake-ups in its history, the ABC board unveiled plans yesterday to abolish most of its traditional internal management structure and pledged to sack 20 per cent of its senior executives in an effort to sae A$27 million a year. The move will see the ABC shed 60 executives as the walls between radio and television are all but dismantled after 13 years of separation. Page 1.

Federal legislation to quash the Northern Territory's controversial euthanasia law was guaranteed passage through the House of Representatives late last night after an almost two-thirds majority, including Prime Minister John Howard, rejected a last-minut attempt to block the legislation on the grounds of States' rights. Page 1.

According to a poll by the Far Eastern Economic Review - one of Asia's top business magazines - more than two-thirds of senior executives in the region say the race debate has made Australia a less attractive place for investment and say they are not satisfied with the Federal Government's handling of the debate over Asian migration. Page 1.

The United Kingdom and the European Union both backed Australia's push for a new "millennium" round of multilateral trade negotiations before the end of the decade and a forward looking free trade agenda concerning information technology and investment also gained support from other industrialised countries at yesterday's world trade talks in Singapore. Page 1.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Under a radical proposal unveiled by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation yesterday, the national broadcaster will shed 60 executives - one in five - and merge its radio and television divisions in an effort to cope with an upcoming A$55 million cut toits budget next year. However, the organisational shake-up will only save A$27 million and the ABC says it may still have no choice but to cut programs. Page 1.

After being held hostage for more than five weeks by Sudanese rebels, Australian Red Cross nurse Maree Worthington, 26, was yesterday released from captivity and was able to ring her mother to tell her she was returning home. Mrs Worthington revealed Maree was twice offered her freedom, but refused to go unless her co-hostages were released too. Page 1.

Following an internal power struggle over political management and policy direction, controversial Queensland Independent Pauline Hanson has dumped her two most senior advisers - John Pasquarelli and her office chief of staff, Jeff Babb - a move which is likely to result in Hanson taking a softer line on some of the issues which have thrust her into national prominence. Page 1.

The assistant general manager of the Department of Community Services' metropolitan north cluster, Margaret Bail, admitted yesterday a five-month-old boy, believed to be Daniel Barkman-Smith, who died after he was left alone in a locked car for several hours in 30-degree heat, was considered a child at risk by the Department. Page 1.
THE AGE

Coles' largest earning employee Peter Bartels is leaving after serving four years with the retail giant. Bartels will hand in his keys six months prior to the expiry date of his contract. Speculation suggests Bartels is leaving to take on a position with the Crown Casino, but he has dismissed these rumours. Page A1.

Following weeks of debate, the House of Representatives voted 91 to 38 in favour of legislation to overturn the Northern Territory's controversial euthanasia law. The Euthanasia Laws Bill seeks to override the powers of the territories to legalise euthanaia - a Bill which, if passed, will affect not only the Northern Territory, but the Australian Capital Territory and Norfolk Island. Page A1.

The stage is now set for a showdown between the ABC and the Federal Government early next year over the proposed A$55 million cut to the national broadcaster's budget, after the ABC unveiled a plan to cut more than A$27 million and at least 60 executive psitions as part of a radical organisational shake-up. Page A1.

The Melbourne Magistrates Court was told yesterday Senior Constable Ashley Clarke, 28, of Flemington Police Station - the first policeman charged with bribery under Operation Bart - was captured on video accepting A$200 and a slab of Victoria Bitter from a policeman posing as a window shutter operator. Page A1.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 373-1800
